ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SSCDS)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by autophony, Tullio's phenomenon, conductive hearing loss with preserved acoustic reflexes, supranormal bone conduction, downbeating nystagmus with humming, massive oVEMP asymmetry, and CT confirmation of dehiscence.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds and identify air-bone gaps characteristic of third-window lesions.
To evaluate word recognition ability, typically preserved in SSCDS.
To assess middle ear function; reflexes are typically present in SSCDS despite conductive loss, distinguishing it from middle ear pathology.
To quantify the handicap from dizziness (DHI) and anxiety/depression levels (HADS).
To evaluate vestibular function and check for nystagmus provoked by sound or pressure (Tullio/Hennebert).
To assess VOR gain across all six semicircular canals.
To assess saccular function; lower thresholds are common in SSCDS.
To assess utricular function; elevated amplitudes and presence of 4000 Hz responses are highly specific for SSCDS.
High-resolution CT is the gold standard to visualize the bony dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation confirms Left Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome. Audiometry shows a low-frequency conductive loss with supranormal bone conduction and preserved acoustic reflexes, a hallmark of third-window pathology. Vestibular testing reveals a massive oVEMP amplitude asymmetry favoring the left ear, the presence of abnormal 4000 Hz VEMP responses on the left, and downbeating nystagmus provoked by humming. CT imaging confirms the dehiscence.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear slight conductive loss; Left ear mild mixed loss (low/mid frequency) with supranormal bone conduction thresholds (-5 to -10 dB HL) and significant air-bone gap.

tests.name: Tympanometry & Reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal tympanograms (Type A) and acoustic reflexes present at normal levels bilaterally, despite the conductive hearing loss.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.result_summary: DHI score 64/100 (severe handicap); HADS Anxiety 18/21 (abnormal); HADS Depression 7/21 (normal).

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) & Calorics
tests.result_summary: Normal ocular motility and calorics (8% right weakness, 19% left directional preponderance). Downbeating nystagmus observed when humming.

tests.name: Video Head Impulse Test (vHIT)
tests.result_summary: Normal VOR gains in all planes (Lateral, RALP, LARP).

tests.name: Cervical VEMP (cVEMP)
tests.result_summary: 500 Hz thresholds relatively symmetrical (atypical), but response present at 4000 Hz in the Left ear (abnormal).

tests.name: Ocular VEMP (oVEMP)
tests.result_summary: Massive amplitude asymmetry (88%) with Left ear response significantly larger; response present at 4000 Hz on the Left side only.

tests.name: CT Imaging
tests.result_summary: Confirmed dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal on the left; normal coverage on the right.

proposed_items: Surgical repair (canal resurfacing or plugging) via middle fossa or transmastoid approach
counseling_actions: Explain the 'third window' mechanism causing sound/pressure to leak into the balance system
Discuss triggers for dizziness (loud sounds, straining) and autophony
Counsel on surgical options versus observation based on quality of life impact

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for surgical evaluation due to severe symptoms and confirmed structural dehiscence.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor symptom resolution, hearing status, and vestibular compensation.

expected_outcome: Postoperative cVEMP: Left and right ear responses were equally scaled with no amplitude asymmetry; VEMP threshold was approximately 85 dB nHL.
Postoperative oVEMP: Left and right ear responses were equally scaled with no amplitude asymmetry; no response was recorded to a 4,000-Hz tone burst on the left side.
Postoperative audiometry: Pure-tone thresholds returned to within normal limits in each ear.
Patient reported all symptoms completely resolved 2 months after surgery following a steroid taper and vestibular rehabilitative therapy.
